Chapter 9, Part 2: Refuting the Attachment to the Self If only the five appropriated aggregates are called pudgala, why did the World-Honored One say:
I will now explain to you the heavy burden, the taking up of the heavy burden, and the one who bears the heavy burden.
What reason is there for the Buddha not to speak of this?
The heavy burden should not be called the bearer itself.
Why is this?
Because it has never been seen.
What cannot be spoken of should also not be spoken of.
Why is this?
Because it has also never been seen.
Moreover, taking up the heavy burden should not be included in the aggregates, because the burden itself takes it up, and this has never been seen.

However, the sutra says that craving is called the one who takes up the burden. Since it is included in the aggregates, the bearer should be the same. The individual is established based on the aggregates.
However, fearing that this pudgala is an inexpressible, permanently abiding real entity, the Buddha himself explained after this sutra:
But in accordance with worldly convention, it is said that this person has such and such a name, and so on.
The passage from the sÅ«tra on humans cited above is to make it clear that this pudgala can be said to be impermanent, not that it really exists.
The five appropriated aggregates themselves are oppressed by their own characteristics and are called the heavy burden.
Because each preceding moment leads to the subsequent moment, it is called the bearer of the burden. Therefore, there is no really existing pudgala.
Pudgala must definitely really exist, because a sÅ«tra says that those who deny the existence of sentient beings born through transformation are included in wrong views.
Who says that there are no sentient beings born through transformation?
As the Buddha said:
Because I say they exist.
It means that the continuity of the aggregates can go to the next world, not by womb, egg, or moisture, but is called sentient beings born through transformation.
Denying their existence is therefore included in wrong views.
Because the aggregates born through transformation really exist.
Moreover, it is admitted that this wrong view denies pudgala.
You should say, which [kind of] elimination is it?
The person is neither eliminated by the path of insight nor by the path of cultivation.
This is not reasonable, because the person is not included among the truths, and because wrong views are not eliminated by the path of cultivation.

If you claim that the scripture that says that there is a person who is born in the world cannot refer to the aggregates, this is not reasonable, because the word one is used metaphorically in reference to the totality, just as one grain of sand, one grain of rice, one heap, one word.
Or else, you must admit that the person is included among the created dharmas, because a scripture says that it is born in the world.
This does not mean that it is born in the same way that the aggregates are newly created. In reference to what can it be said that it is born in the world?
It means that it is born in the sense that it now appropriates different aggregates, just as one says that a priest is born or a logician is born, because they have mastered certain scriptures.
Or else, it is like the expression, a bhiká¹£u is born or a heretic is born, because they have taken on certain observances.
Or else, it is like the expression, an old man is born or a sick man is born, because they are in a different state.
This is not a valid refutation, because the Buddha has already refuted this.
The SÅ«tra on the Emptiness of Ultimate Reality says:
There is action and there is retribution, but the doer is not apprehended.
That is to say, the one who abandons this aggregate and who continues the other aggregates is only the designation of a dharma.
Therefore the Buddha has already refuted this.
The SÅ«tra for PÄrÄyaá¹‡ika also says:
I never say that there is a grasper.
Therefore there definitely is no pudgala that can grasp and abandon the aggregates in the world.
Also, what is the substance of the one born from the sacrifice that you cite as an analogy?
If you hold that it is a self, that is not established for you.
If it is mind and mental activities, they are momentary and newly born in each moment, and therefore grasping and abandoning are not established.
If you admit that it is the body, it is also like mind and so on.
Also, just as light and so on differ from the body, the aggregates must also differ from the pudgala.
The two bodies of old age and sickness are each different from the former. The SÄá¹ƒkhyasâ€™ transformation has already been refuted above. Therefore the analogy that they cite is not established.
Also, if you admit that the aggregates are produced but not the pudgala, you must definitely admit that this pudgala is different from the aggregates and is eternal.
Also, if this pudgala is one and the substance of the aggregates is five, why not say that this pudgala is different from the aggregates?
The four great elements are four, but derivative form is one. Why do you say that derivative form is not different from the great elements?
This is an error in your theory.
What is this theory?
It is the theory of those who maintain that derivative form is the great elements.
If you hold this view, you should be questioned as follows:
Just as derivative form is the four great elements, so also the pudgala should be established as the five aggregates.
If the pudgala is the aggregates, why did the World Honored One not answer that the life-principle is the body?
Because he considered the intention of the questioner.

The questioner held that there is a single internal active person whose substance is real and not empty, and he called this the life-principle. Based on this, he asked the Buddha whether it is the same as or different from the body.
Since this [pudgala] does not exist at all, sameness and difference are not established. How can it be said to be the same as or different from the body?
It is like the question of whether a turtle's hair is rough or smooth. The ancient masters have already unraveled this knot.
In the past, there was a great virtuous one named NÄgÃ¢rjuna, who had the three insights, the six spiritual powers, and was endowed with the eight liberations.
At that time, there was a king named Pá¹›thivÄ«bandhu who went to where the great virtuous one was and said like this:
I now come with the intention of asking about my doubts.
However, Å›ramaá¹‡as tend to speak a lot. If the Venerable One can answer directly, I will ask a question.
The great virtuous one accepted the request.
The king then asked:
Is the life-force the same as the body or different?
The great virtuous one answered:
This should not be answered.
The king said:
Isn't there an agreement already?
Why is it now that you answer differently and do not answer the question?
The great virtuous one asked in return:
I want to ask about my doubts.
However, the nature of the kings tends to speak a lot. If the king can answer directly, I will ask a question.
The king then accepted the teaching.
The great virtuous one asked:ğŸ”½Is the life-force the same as the body or different?
In the king's palace, the fruits produced by the mango trees are sour or sweet.
The king said:
There were originally no such trees in the palace.
The great virtuous one again reprimanded:
Wasn't there an agreement before?
Why do you now speak differently and not answer the question?
The king said:
Since there are no such trees in the palace, how can I answer that the fruit is sour or sweet?
The great virtuous one taught:
Since the life-force does not exist, how can one say it is the same as or different from the body?
Why didn't the Buddha say that the life-force is completely non-existent?
It is also because he observed the intention of the questioner.
The questioner may regard the continuity of the aggregates as the life-force and ask questions based on that.
If the World-Honored One answered that the life-force is completely non-existent, he would fall into wrong views, so the Buddha did not say it.
Because he has not yet understood the principle of dependent origination, he is not a vessel for receiving the true Dharma, and the Buddha did not tell him that it is provisionally existent.
The principle must necessarily be so, because the World-Honored One said so.
As the World-Honored One told Ä€nanda:
There was an ascetic of the Vatsa clan who came to me and asked:
Do I exist in the world or not?
I did not answer him.
Why is that?
If I said he exists, it would contradict the truth of the Dharma, because all dharmas are without self.
If I said he does not exist, it would increase his delusion, as he would think he existed before but now does not.
The delusion of grasping existence is even worse, as grasping a self would fall into the extreme of eternalism, while grasping non-self would fall into the extreme of annihilationism.
The lightness and heaviness of these two are explained in detail in the sutras.
Based on this meaning, there is a verse that says:
Observing the injury caused by views and the destruction of good karma,
Therefore the Buddha taught the true Dharma, like a tigress carrying her cubs.
Grasping the true self as existent is being injured by the fangs of views,
Denying the conventional self as nonexistent destroys the cub of good karma.
Again, a verse is spoken:
Because there is no real self, the Buddha did not say it is the same or different.
Fearing that the provisional self would be denied, he also did not say it is completely non-existent.
He said that in the continuity of the aggregates, there is a self that is the experiencer of the results of karma.
If one says there is no self, they deny this as non-existent.
He did not say that in the aggregates, there is a self that is a provisional designation.
Observing that the questioner lacks the ability to understand true emptiness.
Thus observing the differences in Vatsagotra's intentions,
he did not answer with existence or non-existence when asked about the existence or non-existence of a self.
Why did he not predict the permanence of the world, etc.?
It is also because he observed the intention of the questioner.
If the questioner grasped the self as the world, since the self does not exist at all, all four predictions would be unreasonable.
If one grasped saá¹ƒsÄra as the world, the Buddha's four kinds of predictions would also all be unreasonable.
If it were permanent, there would be no attainment of nirvÄá¹‡a.
If it is impermanent, then it would be destroyed by itself and one would attain nirvÄá¹‡a without effort.
If you say it is both permanent and impermanent, then it is certain that some would attain nirvÄá¹‡a and some would not.
If you say it is neither permanent nor impermanent, then it is neither the case that one attains nirvÄá¹‡a nor that one does not attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
This is a contradiction and thus constitutes idle speculation.
However, one can attain nirvÄá¹‡a by relying on the holy path. Therefore, the four definite answers are all unreasonable.
When the son of Ä€jÄ«vaka asked about the death and rebirth of a sparrow, the Buddha knew his mind and did not give a definite answer.
The four questions about having a limit, etc., are also not to be answered, because they are the same as the errors of permanence, etc.
How do we know that these four have the same meaning as permanence, etc.?
There was a heretic named Udraka who first asked about the world having a limit, etc., and then devised a way to deceptively ask the World Honored One:
Do all worlds attain liberation by the holy path, or only a part?
Venerable Ä€nanda said to him:
You have already asked the World-Honored One about this matter, so why do you change the name and ask about it again now?
Therefore, we know that the latter four are the same in meaning as the former.
For what reason did the World-Honored One not answer the four questions about whether the TathÄgata exists after death, etc.?
It is also because he observed the intention of the questioner. The questioner mistakenly conceived of the self that is liberated as the TathÄgata and asked the question.
Now we should question those who conceive of a self: For what reason did the Buddha answer that a present pudgala exists, but not that the TathÄgata exists after death?
They say it is because he feared falling into the error of permanence.

If so, then why did the Buddha answer Maitreya, You will attain Buddhahood in the future, and also answer, The disciple's body is destroyed and life ends, and so-and-so is now reborn in such-and-such a place?
Isn't this also a case of falling into the error of permanence?
If the Buddha first sees a pudgala and then does not see him after he has entered nirvana, because he does not know whether he exists or not, then this would deny that the Great Master is omniscient.
Or, you must admit that he does not know because the self does not really exist.
If you say that the Buddha sees the self but does not speak of it, then this would be the error of a self apart from the aggregates and of permanence.
If you say that the Buddha both sees and does not see the self, but that neither can be spoken of, then you should say that the Buddha is neither omniscient nor not omniscient.

If you say that the pudgala really exists, because a scripture says that he is the support of truth and of the life of bliss, and because those who definitely hold that there is no self fall into error,
this is not a proof, because that scripture also says that those who definitely hold that there is a self fall into error.
The Abhidharma masters say:
Holding that the self exists or does not exist is a wrong view, because it falls into the errors of eternalism and annihilationism respectively.

The explanation of this master is most reasonable, because if one grasps that there is a self, one falls into the extreme of eternalism, and if one grasps that there is no self, one falls into the extreme of annihilationism.
Because the previous Sutra of Vatsagotra clearly states this.
If there definitely is no pudgala, for whom do you explain that they transmigrate in samsara?
Because samsara itself does not transmigrate.
However, the Blessed One said in the sutras: All sentient beings, covered by ignorance, bound by craving, wander in samsara. Therefore, there must definitely be a pudgala.
How does this [pudgala] transmigrate in samsara?
Because it abandons the previous aggregates and takes up the later aggregates.
This meaning has already been refuted.
Just as a forest fire, although momentary, is said to transmigrate due to its continuity.
In the same way, the aggregates are provisionally called sentient beings, and transmigrate in samsara through craving and grasping as conditions.
If there are only the aggregates, why did the World-Honored One say this?
Now, in the past, I was the world-leading teacher named Wonderful Eyes.
What fault is there in saying this?
Because the aggregates are different.
If so, what is it that is called a person?
The self of the past is precisely the present self, and its substance should be permanently abiding. Therefore, it is said to be the present self.
The statement that the self of the past was the teacher shows that the past and the present are one continuum, just as it is said that this fire once burned that thing.

If it is said that there definitely exists a real self, then only a Buddha should be able to clearly observe it. Having observed it, one should give rise to firm grasping of the self. From this grasping of the self arises the grasping of what belongs to the self. From this, one should give rise to the love of the self and what belongs to the self.
Therefore, the Blessed One said:

If one grasps at the existence of a self, one then grasps at what belongs to the self. Because of grasping at what belongs to the self, one then gives rise to the love of the self and what belongs to the self within the aggregates. Bound by the love of the self, one then slanders the Buddha and is far from liberation.
If it is said that one does not give rise to the love of the self towards the self, this statement is meaningless.
Why is this?
Because one falsely imagines a self in what is not a self and is able to arouse craving for a self.
In what is not a real self, such statements have no reason to serve as proof. Therefore, they have no reason to arise in the true holy teachings of the Buddha.
In this way, one class of people grasps the existence of a person that cannot be spoken of.
There is also a class of people who deny that all dharmas exist.
Non-Buddhists grasp the existence of a separate true self-nature. All of these views are unreasonable and none can avoid the error of no liberation.
If the self-nature of all kinds does not exist at all, how can the mind that ceases in a moment remember and know what was experienced a long time ago in a similar object?
Such memory and knowledge arises from the differences in the mind that remembers the object in a continuum.
Moreover, the initial memory arises from what kind of difference in the mind without interval?
From the power of these conditions, the mind arises in a different mode, and this is called memory.
Even though there are such conditions as attention, if there is no different mode of mind, then there is no ability to cultivate memory.

Even though there is a cause for a different mode of mind, if there are no such conditions, then there is no ability to cultivate memory. Only when both are present is it possible to cultivate memory.
Memory arises only from these two conditions, because we do not see any other power.
How can a different mind see, and a different mind later remember?
It is not reasonable that the mind of Devadatta, having seen an object, the mind of Yajnadatta later remembers it.
This objection is unreasonable, because they are not related.
These two minds are not related to each other, unlike being cause and effect in a single continuity.
We do not say that a different mind sees an object and a different mind can remember it, because the continuity is the same.
However, from the past mind that cognized that object, it induces the present consciousness that is able to remember.
That is to say, as explained above, due to the power of the transformation of the continuity of the series, memory arises. What fault is there?
Due to the power of this memory, there arises a subsequent cognition.
Since the self does not exist, who is the one that remembers?
What is the meaning of is able to remember?
Due to memory, one is able to grasp an object.
Is this grasping of an object different from memory?
Although it is not different from memory, it is simply the agent. The agent is precisely the cause of memory explained above, namely, a specific type of mind.
However, in the world, when it is said that Caitra is able to remember, Caitra is designated in relation to the continuity of the aggregates.
From the mind that sees in the past, later memory arises. Based on this principle, it is said that he is able to remember.
If the self does not exist, whose is this memory?
In what sense is the sixth case used?
This sixth case is used in the sense of belonging to a master. To what does what belong?
It is like cows and so forth belonging to Caitra.
How can it be the master of the cow?
It is said that it has mastery over what it rides, what it milks, and what it makes work, etc.
Where does it drive and direct thought? It diligently seeks the master of thought.
It drives and directs thought towards the object of thought.
What does it do to direct thought?
It causes thought to arise.
How strange that the VaibhÄá¹£ikas make unreasonable statements! Would it rather drive and direct this [self] for the sake of this [thought]?
Moreover, how does it drive and direct thought?
Is it to cause thought to arise or to cause thought to function?
Since thought does not function, it should only cause thought to arise.
Then the cause is called the master and the effect is called what is subject.
Because the cause has supremacy in causing the effect to be born, the cause is called the master.
When the effect is born, it belongs to the cause, so it is called what is subject.
The cause of the arising of thought is sufficient to be the master of thought. Why bother positing a self as the master of thought?
The continuity of a single class of aggregates is conventionally designated as a cow, and the designation of a cow is established as the owner of the cow.
The continuity of this cow is born in a different place, and the cause of the transformation is called the owner.
Here there is not a single real cow, nor is there a real cow, but only a conventional designation, therefore it is said that the cow is the owner, and it is not apart from the cause.
Memory is like this, and so is recollection.
As explained in the discernment of memory, who is the one who is able to understand? Consciousness and so forth should also be explained by analogy.
Moreover, the causes and conditions of consciousness are different from the previous ones, namely the faculties, objects, and so forth, which should be known as appropriate.
Some say:

There definitely exists a self, because the function of things must depend on the one who performs the function.ğŸ”½This means that the function of things depends on the one who performs the function, just as the actions of Devadatta must depend on Devadatta.

Actions are the function of things, and Devadatta is the name. In the same way, the function of things such as consciousness must depend on the support and the one who is able to understand and so forth.
Now we should question them:
What is Devadatta?
If it is a real self, this has been refuted above.
If it is a provisional person, its substance is not a single thing, because this name is provisionally established for the continuity of various activities.
Just as Devadatta can walk, so consciousness can cognize.
On what principle is it said that Devadatta can walk?

It is said that in the continuity of momentary arising and ceasing activities, Devadatta is established without distinction, and the foolish cling to it as a single substance, as the cause for the arising of its own continuity in different places.
The arising in different places is called walking, and the cause is called the walker.
Based on this principle, it is said that Devadatta can walk.
Just as a flame and a sound are said to walk when they arise in continuity in different places, so the world also says that Devadatta can cognize because his body can be the cause of consciousness.
However, the sages also speak in this way in order to conform to the principles of worldly speech.
The scriptures say that consciousnesses are able to perceive objects. What is the function of consciousness with regard to objects?
It has no function at all. It is born with the object as its condition.
It is like a result repaying a cause. Although it has no function, it is said to repay the cause because it arises resembling the cause.
In the same way, although consciousness has no function, it is said to perceive an object because it arises resembling the object.
In what way does it resemble the object?
It means that it takes on the aspect of the object.
Therefore, even though consciousness is born with the support of the organ, it is not said to perceive the organ but is said to perceive the object.

Or, when consciousness is born in a continuous series with regard to an object, the prior consciousness is the cause that attracts the subsequent consciousness, and it is not incorrect to say that consciousness perceives the object, because the world calls the cause the agent.
It is like the world saying that a bell rings or that a lamp moves. The same is true of consciousness perceiving.
On what principle is it based to say that a lamp moves?
The name lamp is provisionally established in the continuity of flames, and when the flame arises in another place, it is said that the lamp moves, but there is no separate mover.
In the same way, the name consciousness is provisionally established in the continuity of mind, and when it arises in relation to another object, it is said to be able to cognize.
Or, just as there is the arising of form, the abiding of form, and the decay of form, but there is no separate arising, abiding, or decaying of form,
the principle of consciousness being able to cognize should be understood in the same way.
If the subsequent consciousness arises from consciousness, not from a self,ğŸ”½why does it not always resemble the previous consciousness?
And why do the subsequent states not arise in a fixed order, like sprouts, stems, leaves, and so on? Because all conditioned dharmas have the characteristics of abiding and changing.
That is to say, it is the intrinsic nature of conditioned dharmas that their subtle continuity must necessarily change.

If it were otherwise, then even if one entered meditative concentration with a certain intention, the continuity of body and mind would arise in a similar way, and the subsequent moments would be no different from the first moment. Therefore, the last moment of consciousness would not naturally emerge from meditative concentration.
The various moments of mind in a continuum also have a fixed order, because if this mind is followed by that mind, then that mind will definitely arise after this mind.
Also, there are some minds that are similar in mode of activity that can produce each other, because their seeds are of the same species.
For example, immediately after a mind of a woman, there may arise a mind to adorn and beautify her body, or there may arise a mind of her husband or son, etc.
Later, from the transformation and development of the continuum of these various minds, a mind of a woman is again produced.

Thus, the mind of a woman has the power to produce the mind of adorning and beautifying herself that arises later, but it does not have the power to produce other minds, because the seeds are of different species.

A mind of a woman may produce many minds immediately after it, but among the many minds, the one that is produced first is the one that has been most frequently produced in the past, the one that was most recently produced, and the one that is most distinct, not the others.
This is because the power of cultivation of this mind is strong. This is not so in the case of the body, because external conditions are different.
Why does the mind that has the strongest power of cultivation not always produce its own effects?
Because the mind has the characteristics of abiding and change. These characteristics of abiding and change are the most suitable for the continuity of the results of separate cultivation.

I have briefly explained the general principles of the causes and conditions for the successive arising of various classes of mind. To thoroughly understand this, one must rely on the World-Honored One, because he has mastery over all dharmas.
Based on this meaning, there is a verse that says:
In a single peacock's wheel, all kinds of causal characteristics,
Are not the domain of other wisdoms, only the Omniscient One knows them.

The causes for the distinctions in form are still difficult to understand, let alone the causes and conditions for the distinctions in the formless dharmas of mind and mental factors, which can be easily understood.
A certain type of non-Buddhist practitioner holds the view that all arising of mind is from the self.
The first two difficulties are the most pressing for them.
If all minds arise from the self, why is it that later consciousnesses are not always similar to the previous ones, and do not arise in an indefinite order, like sprouts, stems, leaves, and so forth?

If you say that the difference in the arising of consciousness is due to the difference in the union of the self and the mind, this is definitely unreasonable, because the union of the self with something else is not established, and also because the union of two things has a limit.
The Vaiseikas themselves explain the characteristic of union, saying that non-contact precedes and subsequent contact is called union.
The union of the self with the mind should have a limit, because the mind moves and the self should move, or it should perish together with the mind.
If you say that there is union in part, this is definitely unreasonable, because there is no distinction in the nature of the single self.
Even if you admit that there is union, since the nature of the self is eternal and the mind is not different, how can union be different?
If you say that the difference is due to the difference in cognition, the objection is the same.
That is, why does cognition have differences?

If the difference in the union of the self and the mind is due to the difference in activity, then consciousness should be able to arise from the difference in activity of the mind alone, waiting for the self to do what?
The self is completely useless in the arising of consciousness, yet you say that all consciousness arises from the self.
Just as when a medicine is effective in curing a chronic illness, a quack doctor falsely claims that the medicine is effective because of the word pasaha.
If it is said that these two exist because of the self, this is merely words, without reason as evidence.
If it is said that the self is the support of these two, like what supports what, in the relationship of support?

The mind and mental factors are not like a painting, and the self is not like the wall or container that holds them. If this were so, there would be the fault of mutual obstruction, and the fault of sometimes abiding separately.
The self is not like a wall or container that supports them.
If so, how is it?
This is merely like the earth, which can be the support for the four things such as smell.
Their statement like this proves the non-existence of self, therefore I deeply rejoice in this.
Just as the worldly earth is not separate from smell, etc., the self should also be like this, not separate from the mind and mental factors.
Who can understand that the earth is separate from smell, etc.?
It is merely in the aggregation and distinction of smell, etc., that the worldly convention of establishing the name earth is spread.
We also are like this. We merely provisionally establish the name self on the basis of the differences among the aggregates of mind, etc.
If there is no earth apart from odor, etc., how can it be said that earth has odor, etc.?

In order to reveal that the substance of earth has the distinction of odor, etc., it is said that earth has odor, etc., in order to cause others to understand that this is that and not something else, just as the world says that an image is made of wood.
Moreover, if there is a self that depends on the differences in the activities of the aggregates, why do not all the consciousnesses arise simultaneously?
When the power of a certain activity is strongest at a certain time, it is able to block the others and prevent them from producing results.
Why is it that the result is not always produced by the strongest?
The answer is that this is like the principle of the power of cultivation previously discussed, because it is admitted that the activities are not permanent and gradually change.
If this is so, then the belief in a self is useless, because the power of the activities produces the differences in the arising of consciousness.

This is because the substance of the practice and cultivation is not different from the self, and you must definitely believe that the substance of the self really exists, because there are such dharmas as memory, etc., and because dharmas must be supported by real substance, and because it is unreasonable that memory, etc., depend on anything else.
This proof is unreasonable, because it is not established.
This means that it is not established that memory, etc., are included among the dharmas, because their substance is not real, and because all those that have a separate substance are called real.
A scripture says that the six real things are called the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Therefore, the reason that memory, etc., depend on a real self is not established.
The meaning of this is as explained above in the refutation of the SarvÄstivÄda. Therefore the proof you have offered is mere empty words.
If the self does not really exist, for whose sake do we create karma?
It is for the sake of the self that will experience the results of happiness and suffering.
What is the substance of the self?
It is the object of the notion of self.
What is the object of the notion of self?
It is the continuity of the aggregates.
How do you know this?
Because we are attached to it.
Because the notion of self and the notion of white, etc., occur in the same place.
There is a saying in the world:
I am fair, I am dark.
I am old, I am young.
I am thin, I am fat.

We see in the world that the perceptions of fair and so on arise in the same place as the attachment to a self, and the self that is imagined does not have these distinctions. Therefore we know that the attachment to a self is only based on the aggregates.
Because the body has the kindness of protecting the self, it is also metaphorically referred to as the self, just as it is said that ministers and so on are one's own body.
In the case of kindness, the self is indeed metaphorically referred to, but this is not the case with the object grasped by the attachment to a self.

If it is admitted that the attachment to a self also arises based on the body, why does the attachment to a self not arise based on the body of another? Because the body of another is not related to the attachment to a self.

That is to say, if the body or mind is related to the attachment to a self, this attachment to a self arises based on that and not on something else, because it has been habituated in this way since beginningless time.
What is meant by being related?
It means having the nature of cause and effect.
If there is no self-entity, whose attachment to a self is it?
This has already been explained, so why bring it up again?

If this is so, on what basis does the attachment to a self arise?
It arises on the basis of the perfuming of the attachment to a self since beginningless time, and it has a defiled mind as its object, a mind that is defiled by the attachment to a self.
If the self does not exist, who experiences suffering and happiness?
If suffering and happiness arise in dependence on something, then that something is said to have suffering and happiness, just as a forest has fruit and a tree has flowers.
On what basis does suffering and happiness exist?
It exists on the basis of the six internal sense bases, and it is said to be the basis of the arising of suffering and happiness.
If the self really does not exist, who is it that performs actions?
Who is it that experiences the results of actions?
What is the meaning of the words â€œto performâ€ and â€œto experienceâ€?
To perform means to be able to act. To experience means to be the one who experiences.
These are merely different names and do not yet reveal the meaning.
Those who discuss the characteristics of dharmas explain the characteristics of the performer and the experiencer as follows:
To be able to act freely is called being the performer.
To be able to receive the results of actions is called being the experiencer.
We see in the world that when one has mastery over an activity, he is called the agent.
For example, when Devadatta is seen to have mastery over bathing, eating, and walking, he is called the bather, the eater, and the walker.
What Devadatta do you speak of here?
If you speak of the real self, the example is not established;
if you speak of the aggregates, it is not the self-sufficient agent.
There are three kinds of actions: bodily, verbal, and mental.

Bodily action necessarily depends on body and mind. Body and mind each depend on their own causes and conditions. The causes and conditions, in turn, depend on their own causes and conditions. There is not a single self-sufficient agent among them, because all conditioned things belong to causes and conditions.
The self you posit does not depend on causes and conditions, nor does it do anything. Therefore it is not self-sufficient.
For this reason, the characteristic of being called the agent by being self-sufficient, as they say, cannot be found.

However, in the causes and conditions that produce dharmas, if there is a dominant function, we provisionally call it an agent. The self that is grasped does not have the slightest function and therefore definitely should not be called an agent.
What is the dominant cause that produces bodily action?
It is said that from memory there arises desire, from desire there arises seeking, from seeking there arises zeal, from zeal there arises wind, and from wind there arises bodily action.
What use is there for the self that you grasp in this process?
Therefore the self is not the agent of bodily action.
The arising of vocal and mental actions should be considered in the same way.
How can the self experience the results of action?

If you say that the self is able to perceive the results of action, this is definitely not so. The self has no function at all in the act of perceiving, because this has already been refuted in the discussion of the causes of the production of consciousness.
If there really is no self, how can sin and merit arise and increase in dependence on nonliving things?
Because they are not the support of love, etc., only the six internal sense bases are their support.
We are not that support, as has been explained above.
If there really is no self, and action has already been destroyed, how can it again produce a future effect?
Even if there really is a self, and action has already been destroyed, how can it again produce a future effect?
Dharma and non-dharma arise from the self as support.
Who supports whom? This has been refuted above. Therefore dharma and non-dharma should not be supported by the self.
However, the holy teachings do not say that the future effect arises from action that has already been destroyed.
If so, from what?
From the transformation and differentiation of the continuity of action, like a seed producing a fruit.
It is said in the world that a fruit arises from a seed.
However, the fruit does not arise from a seed that has already been destroyed, nor does it arise immediately after the seed.
If so, from what?

The fruit arises from the transformation and differentiation of the continuity of the seed, that is, the seed first produces the sprout, stem, leaves, etc., and the flower is the last to attract the production of the fruit.
If this is so, why is it said that the effect arises from the seed?
Because the seed, through a series of transformations, finally produces in the flower a special power to generate the effect, and for that reason it is said that the effect arises from the seed.
If the special power to generate the effect in the flower were not produced by the seed, then the effect generated would not be the same as the seed.

In the same way, although it is said that the effect arises from action, it does not arise from action that has already perished, nor does it arise immediately from the action, but rather it arises from a transformation and development of the series of actions.
What is meant by transformation and development of the series?
Action is prior, and then form and mind arise, and there is no interruption in the middle; this is called the series.
This series is different in each subsequent moment from the prior one; this is called transformation.
This transformation, at the final moment, has a special power to immediately generate the effect, superior to the other transformations, and for that reason it is called special.

When a consciousness that appropriates a body is about to die, even though it is accompanied by many actions that attract a subsequent existence, the perfuming that is attracted by the most serious, the most recent, the most frequently performed, and the most familiar is clear and not the others.
As a verse says,
Actions that are most serious, most recent, most frequently performed, and those performed first,
These ripen first in that order, and one cycles through samsara.

In this interpretation, there is a difference in the power to give results as retribution that is attracted by the cause of results as retribution. This power ceases to exist as soon as it has given its result.

The power to give results as similar cause that is attracted by the cause of similar results ceases to exist when the antidote to the impure arises. The power of the pure cause of similar results ceases to exist forever at the time of nirvÄá¹‡a, because form and mind in their series cease forever at that time.
Why is it that a result as retribution cannot attract another result as retribution, as another result is born from a seed?
First, this is not a simile, because all dharmas are equal.
However, another result is not born from a seed.
If this is so, from what does the subsequent effect arise?
It arises from the transformation of the subsequent ripening.
That is, the previous seed encounters conditions such as water and soil that transform it, and it is able to give rise to a transformation of ripening.
Only when the sprout is just arising is it called a seed. Before it has been transformed, it is said to have a future name, or it is said to be a seed because it resembles a seed.

This is also like this. The previous ripening encounters conditions that give rise to good or evil, such as hearing the correct or heretical teachings, and it is able to give rise to wholesome dharmas with outflows and unwholesome dharmas with ripening. From this, a continuity and transformation is produced, and it is able to lead to a transformation and distinction. From this distinction, the subsequent ripening arises, not from anything else.
Therefore, the analogy is the same as the dharma.

Or, by means of another dharma, this can be known. It is like a mango flower that is dyed with the juice of purple mineral. The transformation and distinction of the continuity is the cause. When the subsequent fruit arises, the pulp then has a red color. From this red color, no other color arises.
In this way, you should understand that from the karmic retribution, it cannot again induce another birth of karmic retribution.
Up to now, I have simply followed the realm of my own wisdom, and have briefly revealed the coarse characteristics of the karmic fruits.

The various different kinds of abilities, the perfuming of the various karmas, the transformation of the continuity, reaching that state and producing that fruit, are only realized by the Buddha and are not the realm of others.
Relying on this meaning, there is a verse that says:
This karma and this perfuming, reaching this time and producing the fruit,
The principle of all kinds is certain, apart from the Buddha, there is no one who can know it.

One should abandon the blind darkness of all external attachments, and the evil views that are created, seeking the wisdom-eye.
